Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellows: Atmospheric Water Transport from Mexico to the U.S. - A Holistic, Binational Approach to Reducing Vulnerability to the North American Monsoon
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will explore the impacts of changes in land cover/land use in northwestern Mexico on moisture recycling and transport to both the United States and other areas of Mexico, using a coupled land-atmosphere model. The feasibility of employing land use decisions to influence the North American monsoon and thereby reduce regional vulnerability to climate variability and change will be assessed. The study will be embedded within an integrated assessment framework, in which scientists and stakeholders from both sides of the border interact and co-develop both the model experiments and a decision-support tool. Stakeholders will be involved in guiding the form of the experiments and the form of the tool, and in evaluating the tool?s performance as an aid to decisions in the context of sustainable resource management.

A substantial portion of summer precipitation in the southwestern United States originates from land in northwestern Mexico and is transported across the border via the phenomenon of moisture recycling during the monsoon. Research also indicates that land use decisions in northwestern Mexico may have a large influence over the timing and magnitude of this moisture recycling, and on the behavior of the monsoon itself. The potential link between land use and downwind precipitation could represent a major paradigm shift, affecting our concepts of water rights and international treaties and making bi-national cooperation in land use crucial to sustainable water resources management. The scientific results and adaptive strategies investigated in this project will be applicable to the U.S.-Mexico border region, as well as to other arid regions and monsoon systems, and to the international coordination of shared resources around the world.

This project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. With SEES Fellows support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish themselves in an independent research career related to sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intended goals of this project were to: (a) investigate the possibility that land and water management in northwestern Mexico could influence rainfall in the southwestern US, and (b) meet with stakeholders (land and water users and managers) on both sides of the border to discuss how our findings might impact coordinated land and water management between the two countries.

Unfortunately, we were not able to achieve these goals within the time frame of the project. The mechanism that would transport water from Mexico to the US would consist of evapotranspiration (ET) at the land surface returning moisture to the atmosphere that otherwise would run off into the ocean. This moisture would then be blown northward into the southwestern US by the summer monsoon. From hydrologic modeling, we were able to identify two main sources of ET in northwestern Mexico: irrigated agriculture and mountain forests.  However, we also discovered that farmers in Mexico generally do not irrigate during the summer, when the monsoon winds blow from Mexico to the US; most irrigation is during the winter, when winds would transport any evaporated moisture towards the interior of Mexico. Furthermore, although ET from mountain forests transports a large amount of water to the atmosphere during the summer, deforestation in northwestern Mexico did not appear to change the amount of ET by more than a few percent. Thus, it appeared that land and water management in northwestern Mexico would not have much influence over rainfall in the southwestern US.

However, the work we performed for this project did have some useful outcomes. First, we made several improvements to a major hydrologic model that made it much more accurate in arid and semi-arid climates such as the US-Mexico border region, including (1) accounting for soil evaporation from spaces between plants in areas of sparse vegetation; (2) enabling the model to account for changes in the vegetation from year to year, to account for the vegetation's response to variability in monsoon rainfall; and (3) more accurate representation of the diurnal cycle of rainfall when given only information on daily total rainfall.

Second, we developed land surface inputs to the hydrologic model with the following improvements: (1) higher resolution sampling of land surface characteristics taken from remote sensing datasets; (2) inclusion of information about the amount of space between plants; (3) interannual variation in land surface characteristics; (4) interannual and seasonal variation in irrigated area, informed by government records from the US and Mexico; (5) interannual variation in urban water use, informed by government records from the US and Mexico; (6) decadal changes in land use from 1992 to 2011, derived from remote sensing datasets; and (7) coverage over the entirety of the continental US and Mexico.

Third, we examined how changes in land use in the period after the 1994 NAFTA agreement impacted water use on both sides of the US-Mexico border. We found that production of fresh fruits and vegetables for consumption in the US was outsourced to Mexico, along with extraction of local groundwater to irrigate these crops. Over the same period, agricultural irrigation in the southwestern US declined as croplands were replaced by urban land use, which uses less water per unit area than irrigated crops. Thus, the southwestern US saved water by urbanizing and enforcing limits on water use. In Mexico, where water is poorly regulated, very little crop-urban conversion occurred, and Mexican water use increased substantially. This illustrates the unintended consequences of well-meaning land and water management policies helping conserve resources at the local scale but encouraing unsustainable resource consumption elsewhere.
